initial_story:
Thanks for joining our live coverage on an extraordinary day in court, with adult-film star Stormy Daniels taking the stand.

It was a tense courtroom, with Daniels warned to dial back her comments at times. Prosecutors were also told to limit their questions regarding the salacious details of her alleged sexual encounter with Trump (which Trump has denied ever took place).

Here's our full wrap of what happened in court today.

This page was edited by Tiffany Wertheimer, Lisa Lambert, Brandon Livesay and Phil McCausland. The writers were Sam Hancock and Sean Seddon, and we had Madeline Halpert and Kayla Epstein in court.

Court doesn't sit on Wednesday, so we'll be back on Thursday, when Stormy Daniels will once again take to the stand to continue her testimony.

As you can see, there were some very interesting developments today. First of all, it seems like the prosecution is trying to keep things as clean as possible. They didn't want to bring up any sordid details about what might have happened between Ms. Daniels and President Trump. That said, they did manage to get her to admit that she had been paid $130,000 by Mr. Cohen, which she claims was meant to buy her silence. She also testified that she signed an agreement saying she wouldn't talk about the affair publicly. However, she later claimed that this agreement was void because she never actually received the money. So now we know exactly how much money she was paid, but we still don't know whether she actually had sex with the President. It remains unclear if she will be able to prove that she did. In addition, the defense team brought up several other witnesses who testified that they knew nothing about the alleged affair. One woman even went so far as to say that she saw Ms. Daniels at a party where she appeared to be very drunk. Another man said that he overheard her talking to someone else about the incident. These people weren't exactly objective observers, but their testimony certainly raised doubts about Ms. Daniels' credibility. Overall, I think today was a pretty interesting day in court. We got to hear from both sides, and we learned a lot more about what happened between Ms. Daniels and the President. It'll be fascinating to see where this case goes next.

As we reported earlier today, the judge overseeing the trial has decided to allow the jury to hear evidence of President Trump's relationship with another woman, Karen McDougal. According to court documents filed yesterday, Ms. McDougal alleges that she had an affair with Mr. Trump while he was still married to Melania Trump. The affair reportedly lasted for about a year, beginning in 2006. During that time, Mr. Trump reportedly gave Ms. McDougal gifts, including jewelry and expensive watches. He also allegedly offered to pay her off in order to keep quiet about their relationship. In fact, according to the lawsuit, Mr. Trump asked Ms. McDougal to sign a non-disclosure agreement preventing her from speaking publicly about their relationship. Ms. McDougal claims that she refused to sign the agreement, and that she was never compensated for her silence. Now, it looks like the judge has decided to allow the jury to hear this evidence, despite objections from the prosecution. According to the judge, the testimony could be relevant to the case since it involves allegations of infidelity by Mr. Trump. And while the defense argues that the testimony is irrelevant, the judge seems to disagree. It's unclear exactly what impact this new development will have on the case, but it certainly adds another layer of complexity to an already complicated situation. Stay tuned for more updates as the trial continues.
